questions.question: Which of the following cells in the olfactory bulb lacks an axon?
questions.explanation: bulb. Their unique characteristic is the loss of axons, but have multiple branched-out dendrites. Olfactory bulb connection: The synapse between the bipolar neuron and the second-order neuron occurs within the olfactory bulb. The second-order neuron belongs to the categories of mitral and tufted cells , which serve as projection neurons. The specialised structure where these connections occur is termed glomeruli within the olfactory bulb. Between the first-order (bipolar) and second-order (mitral and tufted) neurons, two additional cell types exist: Periglomerular cells function as inhibitory neurons. Granule cells are also inhibitory neurons ; they lack axons but possess dendrites, enabling dendrodendritic synapses. Both types of inhibitory neurons play roles in refining and concentrating olfactory signals.

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the pathway of taste perception from the tongue to the brain? thalamus

options.A: Taste signals from the taste buds are first transmitted to the gustatory cortex via CN VII, IX & X
options.B: The taste receptors generate nerve impulses relayed to the nucleus of the solitary tract in the medulla.
options.C: From the nucleus of the solitary tract, taste signals travel to the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the
options.D: The gustatory cortex, responsible for taste perception, is located in the medulla oblongata,

questions.explanation: tract in the medulla. the medulla. Explanation: Taste Receptors on Tongue: The journey begins with the taste receptors on the tongue, responsible for detecting the five primary tastes: sour, salty, sweet, bitter, and umami. These receptors are located in taste buds. Cranial Nerves: Taste signals are transmitted from the taste buds to the brain stem via three cranial nerves: the facial nerve (VII), the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX), and the vagus nerve (X). Nucleus of the Solitary Tract in the Medulla: These cranial nerves carry the taste information to a specific nucleus in the medulla oblongata called the nucleus of the solitary tract. (Option A) Ventral Posterior Medial Nucleus of the Thalamus: From the nucleus of the solitary tract, the taste signals are relayed to the ventral posterior medial nucleus of the thalamus. (Option C) Gustatory Cortex: Finally, the taste signals are transmitted from the thalamus to the gustatory cortex, the primary area responsible for processing taste perception in the brain. This region is located in the lower portion of the postcentral gyrus, extending into a part of the insular cortex. (Option D)

Piriform cortex: Responsible for the perception of a smell. (Option A) Amygdala: Mediated the emotional responses to olfactory stimuli. (Option C) Entorhinal cortex: Concerned with olfactory memories . (Option B) Sequence of events in Olfactory cortex: The second-order neuron travels to the cortex via the lateral olfactory tract. The lateral olfactory tract originates from the olfactory bulb, specifically from the glomeruli, and extends into different areas of the olfactory cortex. Some of these fibers project to the thalamus, which then relays signals to the orbitofrontal cortex. The orbitofrontal cortex is involved in the conscious perception and discrimination of odors. The pathway traverses the mediodorsal (dorsomedial) thalamic nucleus (MDT) and the orbitofrontal cortex, forming the new olfactory cortex together. Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK55970/

questions.question: A 38-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of sensitivity to light and occasional blurriness in his vision. During the physical examination,When light is shone into his right eye, both pupils constrict normally andWhen light is shone into his left eye, only the left pupil constricts. Given these observations, which of the following connections of the pathway is most likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Pretectal nucleus and Edinger-Westphal nucleus Explanation: If there is a lesion between the pretectal nucleus and the contralateral Edinger-Westphal nucleus, the ability to coordinate the consensual light reflex between the two eyes will be impaired, resulting in failure of light reflex in the right eye when the light is shone on the left eye. This would result in the left pupil constricting when light is shone into the left eye (direct reflex intact) but failing to cause the right pupil to constrict (impaired consensual reflex) as supposedly the connections are impaired between the right Edinger-Westphal nucleus and the pretectal nucleus.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the structure of the cochlea? tympani. transmitting sound waves directly to the auditory nerve.

options.A: The cochlea is a part of the outer ear and contains the ossicles.
options.B: The cochlea is divided into three fluid-filled compartments: the scala vestibuli, scala media, and scala
options.C: The organ of Corti, which contains hair cells responsible for hearing, is located in the scala vestibuli.
options.D: The basilar membrane separates the scala media from the scala tympani and is responsible for

questions.explanation: scala media, and scala tympani. media, and scala tympani. Explanation: The cochlea is a spiral-shaped organ in the inner ear, essential for hearing. It consists of three main compartments: Scala vestibuli: The upper chamber filled with perilymph. Scala media (cochlear duct): The middle chamber filled with endolymph and contains the organ of Corti. Scala tympani: The lower chamber filled with perilymph. The organ of Corti is located in the scala media and contains hair cells that detect sound vibrations and convert them into electrical signals sent to the brain. Option A. The cochlea is a part of the outer ear and contains the ossicles. The cochlea is part of the inner ear, not the outer ear. The ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes) are located in the middle ear, not in the cochlea. Option C. The organ of Corti, which contains hair cells responsible for hearing, is located in the scala vestibuli. The organ of Corti is located in the scala media, not the scala vestibuli. The scala vestibuli is one of the fluid-filled compartments but does not contain the organ of Corti. Option D. The basilar membrane separates the scala media from the scala tympani and is responsible for transmitting sound waves directly to the auditory nerve. While the basilar membrane does separate the scala media from the scala tympani and plays a crucial role in sound wave propagation, it does not transmit sound waves directly to the auditory nerve. The hair cells on the basilar membrane convert mechanical vibrations into electrical signals, which are then transmitted to the auditory nerve by synaptic connections.

Explanation: Neurons of Visual Pathway: First-order neurons : Photoreceptor cells (rods and cones) in the retina. Second-order neurons : Ganglion cells in the retina. Third-order neurons : Neurons in the thalamus's lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN). Neuronal Cell Types in the Retina: Function Photoreceptors (Rods and cones) Transmit signals to the outer plexiform layer. They connect with bipolar and horizontal cells. Horizontal Cells Transmit signals horizontally in the outer plexiform layer. Connect rods and cones to bipolar cells. Bipolar Cells Transmit signals vertically from rods, cones, and horizontal cells. Connect with ganglion cells and amacrine cells in the inner plexiform layer. Amacrine Cells Transmit signals in two ways: directly from bipolar cells to ganglion cells or horizontally within the inner plexiform layer. Connect axons of bipolar cells to dendrites of ganglion cells or other amacrine cells. Ganglion Cell Transmit output signals from the retina to the brain via the optic nerve. Interplexiform Cells Transmit inhibitory signals retrogradely from the inner to the outer plexiform layer. Control the lateral spread of visual signals by horizontal cells, potentially enhancing visual contrast.

questions.question: What is the primary mechanism by which an odorant molecule leads to the depolarisation of an olfactory cell?

options.B: Triggers the breakdown of cyclic adenosine monophosphate
options.C: Initiating a signalling cascade that ultimately opens sodium ion channels.
options.D: The odorant molecule is transported into the olfactory cell, where it directly depolarises

questions.explanation: Mechanism of Olfactory signaling: Single cilia (as shown in the picture) have olfactory receptors that are G protein-coupled receptors. Odorants activate G protein, which increases cyclic AMP (cAMP) (Option B) as a second messenger. cAMP opens non-specific cation channels in the cilium, allowing calcium and sodium ions to enter, causing depolarization. Depolarization above a threshold (-30 mV) generates action potentials in bipolar sensory neurons. Action potentials are transmitted to the olfactory bulb. Calcium-gated chloride channels in the cilium further amplify depolarization. Chloride ions move out due to increased calcium, reducing negative charge and enhancing positivity inside the cell. This amplification process facilitates action potential generation and transmission to the olfactory bulb. (Option A) Odorant molecules don't close sodium channels but They initiate a signaling cascade for that lead to opening of Na channel (Option D) Odorant molecules don't need to enter the olfactory cell; binding to external receptors is sufficient to trigger the signaling cascade. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 679-680

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman visits her ophthalmologist complaining of difficulty seeing in low-light conditions. She reports that her vision is fine during the day but deteriorates significantly at night. Based on your understanding of the visual pathway mechanisms in light versus dark conditions, which of the following best explains her symptoms?

options.A: Increased activity of rod cells in bright light.
options.B: Increased neurotransmitter release from photoreceptors in the dark.
options.C: Increased depolarisation of photoreceptors in the presence of light.
options.D: Decreased cGMP levels in photoreceptors during darkness.

questions.explanation: dark: Rods and cones are depolarised due to the high levels of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). cGMP binds to and opens cGMP-gated sodium (Na+) channels known as Funny Current Sodium Channels. Sodium ions (Na+) flow into the photoreceptors, keeping them depolarised. Depolarised photoreceptors continuously release the neurotransmitter glutamate at their synaptic terminals. This glutamate release inhibits bipolar cells, preventing signal transmission to the ganglion cells and, subsequently, to the brain. In light: Light photons are absorbed by photopigments (rhodopsin in rods, photopsins in cones). This absorption activates a G-protein called transducin. Transducin activates phosphodiesterase (PDE), an enzyme that breaks down cGMP. The decrease in cGMP levels causes cGMP-gated sodium channels to close. The closure of sodium channels leads to hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor membrane. Hyperpolarized photoreceptors reduce the release of glutamate. The decrease in glutamate release allows bipolar cells to become active, transmitting signals to ganglion cells and then to the brain, resulting in visual perception. Option A. Rod cells are not primarily active in bright light; they are more sensitive to low light. In bright light, rod cells are saturated and do not function effectively. Option C. Light exposure causes hyperpolarization of photoreceptors, not depolarization. Light reduces the intracellular cGMP levels, leading to the closure of sodium channels and hyperpolarization. Option D. In darkness, cGMP levels are high, keeping the sodium channels open and the photoreceptors depolarized.

questions.question: Which of the following best explains why rods are more sensitive to low light than cones?
questions.explanation: highly convergent onto ganglion cells. This means that multiple rod cells synapse onto a single ganglion cell. This high level of convergence allows for the pooling of signals from many rods. Consequently, even small amounts of light can trigger a response because the signals from multiple rods are combined and sent as a single, stronger signal to the brain. This increases the sensitivity of rods to low light conditions. While convergence enhances sensitivity, it reduces spatial resolution. Since multiple rods converge onto a single ganglion cell, the specific location of light cannot be as accurately determined, leading to less detailed vision. Non-Convergence in Cones: Cones generally have a more direct, one-to-one connection with ganglion cells, especially in the fovea. As a result, they are less sensitive to low light compared to rods. Each cone needs a stronger light stimulus to activate the associated ganglion cell. The direct connection of cones to ganglion cells allows for high spatial resolution. Each cone contributes a distinct signal to the brain, enabling detailed and sharp vision. Individual connections to ganglion cells (Option A): This is true for cones, not rods. Cones connect individually to ganglion cells, especially in the fovea, which provides high spatial resolution but lower sensitivity. Lower density in the retina (Option C): Rods are more densely packed in the peripheral retina, which contributes to their sensitivity to low light, but the primary reason for their high sensitivity is their convergence onto ganglion cells. Larger size of photoreceptors (Option D): The size of the photoreceptors does not significantly impact their sensitivity to light. Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 190,191
